element_texts.text:
4 square de Verdun, Paris, 1oe
Le 27 decembre 1948
Dear Jack
My very best wishes for the New Year, to you and all the Conroys, wife, sons and daughter -- and doggie. There are still a few days for hoping 1949 will be a year of peace and freedom and justice and plenty... before we begin to be disappointed. Still a few days when we can believe that in 1949, the United States will unclear something else than spending money, that the French budget will be balanced, and that Mr. Truman will start a New Deal!
So let's be happy for the rest of the year.

Your fellow countryman Garry Davis has become a very popular figure here. Because his ideas are so very cloudy, he has rallied all the French people who hate the Soviet Union though they don't want to wage a war against the Soviet Union, who dislike the United States though they definitely don't want to fight against the United States, who dislike every other country but don't want a war against any country. And that mean a majority of the French people. Speaking peace is easy in France. France is pacifist and has been so for decades -- ever since the First World War. Which didn't prevent the Second World War. 
But let's hope everybody will turn pacifist in 1949. The Dutch will let the Indonesians live as they please -- the capitalists will be so pacifist that they'll give away their plants to the workers. All that good will will melt the iron curtain and our earth will be a parade. 
Most cordially,
Chenneviere

postcard
postmark CORREOS DE GUATEMALA 06  GUATEMALA CA  22 XI 66
Mixca Viejo (Guatemala). Dec 15, 66
Dear Jack and Gladys, thanks for your nice card, and our best wishes for 67
We are back in Guatemala, Henri wants to finish up his excavations in
Mixca Viejo during this dry season - Coming here we spent two months in
South America, the picture is Machu Pichu in Peru. Before leaving Paris, I sent
my last copy of the Disinherited to Michel Fabre, to give to a publisher. I insisted
to review the translation if the publisher accepts it, because it is not the definitive
copy which seems to have got lost. Let's hope it's going to work this time. Yours as ever, and
here is our address! Embajada de Francia - Guatemala.
Par avion/
Mr. and Mrs. Jack Conroy
701 Fisk Avenue
Moberly  Mo 65270
E.E.U.U.

left side - handwritten
You'll be interested to hear about it.
I am turning a new leaf -
But just the same, I remain

Suzanne Chenneviere

right side- printed
MONSIEUR HENRI LEHMANN
Sous-Directeur du Muses De L'Homme
MADAME SUZANNE CHENNEVIERE
Ont Le Plaisir De Vous Faire Part De Leur Mariage.
Paris - October 1961
15. Rue Jean-Jacques-Rousseau (1st)   4. Square De Verdun (10th)

Dear Jack and Gladys, we've wondered if you came to Europe last Summer. we were out in the country most of
the time, Henri alone went to the U.S. Washington, Philadelphia and New York) for a congress. But I doubt you were in Paris,
you surely would have let us know - Our plans for a campaign in Guatemala 1965/66 had to be postponed till the following
season and we'll probably spend the first part of 66 in Paris.  Yesterday was election day - doomsday for de Gaulle. Everybody
knew in advance he was going to loose a good many votes, but such a severe blow was not expected. I wonder what is going to
come next, it's interesting -  We both send regards to you and Gladys       Suzanne

left side - printed
Miss Levin of Evanston
is "Going to Town"
August 1, 1971
may be reached at
2800 Lake Shore Drive
Chicago, Illinois 60657
Phone: 936-3313
right side - handwritten
Should be settled with my kitchen in
working order by the 15th -
All when you All in town and this time
you'll have a lovely view with dinner.

 Henri

El Baul (Guatemale). Stele.    Joueur de pelote. [ball player]

Henri et Suzanne Lehman
vous adressent leurs meilleurs voeux
pour la novelle annee

decembre 1967

see translation



We are glad to send our best wishes for the new year 1967

Dear Jack and Gladys,

Back in Paris since last Summer, I still don't feel quite re-adapted to
parisian life. I miss the Guatemalan Indians...and the sun - No chance of
my crossing the Atlantic in 1968. Henri will, to prepare a Maya exhibition
that will take place here in the Spring. Or next step may be Japan (for a congress
in August 68) and then Cambogia [sic] (far Angkor) - if the political situation allows it!
Just got a ring from Michel Fabre who is going to send me back the translation of the
Disinherited. Sorry it won't be published. But if the best sellers point to the French public taste,
the Disinherited have not much chance right now.

Congratulations for your getting the Iow [Iowa?] Award, I am sure you got some satisfaction out of it,

and it gives me joy also -

A very happy year for you both, health and wealth.... and let's hope for a peaceful world!
  Suzanne

card
image of Maya man carved in stone
Bas-relief d'une stele maya (9 siecle) [9th century]
Seibal - Guatemala.
Henri et Suzanne Lehman
vous presentent
leurs meilleurs voeux pour 1969



We are glad to send our best wishes for the new year 1969

Dear Jack,

Coming back from Japan and Cambodgia [sic], I find your booklet "Home to Moberly", and as I am starting to write

to thank you and to send season's greetings, here comes your Christmas card with a clipping from the Kansas City Star
So I see that, even though you are "retired", you keep on with your writing, and I am glad of it. Just go on, you certainly
still have much to say.  
We went to Japan for a congress of anthropology, but as a country, it made a deep impression on us.  Somewhat frightened me: 
one hundred million people, so energetic, so faithful to their way of life under a mask of modernism, and in such a small country!  
Cambodgia [sic] was a wellcome [sic] rest. We spent twelve days in Angkor: exuberant forest, astounding ruins, smiling, slow 
indolent people. After all, I feel happier in backward countries than in over industrialized ones.
Here in France, the situation is worrying. The students' rising of last may/june still lingers on, there is a lot of anarchism among the
young. On the other hand, surprisingly the capital seems to play against de Gaulle! It's all very strange and quite uncomfortable. Nobody
can guess what the near future will be made of. Let's hope for the best. For you and Gladys, a very happy new year and our friendly
souvenir*      Suzanne

remembrance or memory

card photo of children
A la fête de Rabinal.
(Guatemala)
Henri et Suzanne Lehmann
vous presentest leurs
meilleurs voeux pour 1971



We are glad to send our best wishes for 1971

Out in Guatemala three months, later a visit to Belgium (Brussels, Bruges, Gand* etc. - very pleasant), a few trips to
different places in France. But we've been here since october, and the youngsters you announced never showed up.
We were in Angkor in 68 - huge and glorious site, such lovely people, so peaceful! It was only for a visit, Henri only
digs in central or south America. But Angkor is the siege of the French School of the Far east and is being reconstructed
by French archeolgists. I believe it has been saved from the war thanks to the presence of the French chief of the mission -
who is still there, though no work can be done now. It's unbearable thinking of war among such quiet people.

 As ever   S. L.

[* Gand is the French spelling of Ghent]

postcard of watercolor of Paris with Eiffel Tower and bridge
17 Paris - Le Pont Alexandre III [bridge]

Very best wishes for 1975, though there is every reason to believe it's not going to be a pleasant year. The fact
of having been denouncing the dangers of capitalist enterprises for ages doesn't help individually. We are in
a mess, everyone of us.   
While I am thinking over these sad thoughts, Henri is excavating in Guatemala once more,
and very satisfied with his research. I found it too tiring for me to accompany him this year.

My best to Gladys      S. Lehmann

card

Que la paz y alegria de Navidad, perduren todo el

Ano Nuevo

see translation
handwriting
that's a pious wish - But for the present, we are in a mess! Unless
this petroleum crisis is only a make-believe, to slower somewhat our
foolish expansion - that I would welcome, but I am afraid of unemployment.
Henri is here in Guatemala studying the Maya people of San Andres
Sajcabaja (a pretty name, no?) from their remote past up to the present day.
I joined him for a few weeks, but will soon return to Paris and the worries of
highly civilized peoples.  From both of us, best wishes to both of you.   S. Lehmann



May the peace and joy of Christmas be with you throughout the New Year

Dear Jack,

 The flowers you, Jerry, and his family sent to the church

for Dad's service were beautiful, and it made us feel good
to know you were thinking about us. I know Mother is
writing you an "official" note but I

wanted to add my own postscript.

 I'm anxious to see you again soon and know how you

are feeling.  You looked so much better when I saw you
the 21st (I think it was).... 'Till soon,

 Love, Suzanne

P.S. We'll arrange for Bill Trogdon to come visit you this spring.
printed
BUTTERFLIES

Dear Jack

Best wishes for you and all the Conroys.

I saw two of your friends lately, Miss
Anziss and Mr Lust and from both of them
I got a notion of the present state of minds

in the States. May I tell you that I consequently
felt rather anxious -

Cordially yours just the same
  S Chenneviere

in pencil  Lehmann-Chenneviere, Suzanne [no date]
Paris. 4 square de Verdun (10*)
Dear Jack, thanks for your good wishes and the same to you and Mrs Conroy. I was sorry to hear
about your son Tom being separated from his wife - and little boy. You probably miss that child
and the child will miss his father too. It's too bad!

You got it quite right about Sonia Raizics[?] I was somewhat abashed at her reasoning, thinking

that she probably was considered as a radical in the States. But something funny has happened. 
I saw her again, recently, since she has remained in Paris all this time. She invited me together
with a group of American "exiles" in Paris, and all of them sang a quite different tune this time -
this year - events seem to have taught them something. And I was quite satisfied for Sonia R.'s sake
(who by the way got married in the meantime to some Italian whom I haven't had the opportunity
to talk much to)    You know, Jack, I am feeling rather uncomfortable in this world where my best
American friends can't come to France.
printed, on side  Meilleurs Voeux [Best wishes]

and I can't go to America. Well, may be we couldn't afford to anyway, but feeling you are
forbidden is much worse. It reminds me of the way we felt towards the Germans, during the war,
when they forbade us to go away - crossed out to so many places. Still we French people are
more privileged than you are; we can get out and in as we wish. Last summer, I book a trip to
England and Scotland which I enjoyed much - I didn't go to Ireland, though for your sake I should
have! Good luck, Jack, and let's hope things will mend -

 Bien amicalement a vous deux        S. Chenneviere

Best wishes to you two

July 25th
Dear Jack,
thank you for sending me your April Anthology. It reached me just before we left for a few weeks rest in Normandy (Apparently it took more than a month from Moberly to Paris).
It's interesting the re-reading of this American proletarian literature of the 30's. this evocation of the depression years in the States--in particular of the first years, when the American public would say, as you recall; "Just disregard the Depression and maybe it'll go away", apply very well to the situation in France right now--Drastic economical and financial measures are required, but nobody will have courage enough to take them--and certainly not Giscard d'Estaing, who has been elected president with so small a majority and cannot rely on the public opinion. Anyway, it's not only a French crisis, it's international. A regime crisis, the crisis of capitalism, of profit production, of "la société de consommation"--

I consider the Nixon case as one more illustration of the deliquescence of politics - But how skillfull the man is! I wonder what trick
he'll use to get out once more, now the Supreme Court decided he must communicate his files?

To come back to the Anvil Anthology, I must say your "Happy hollow" is one of the best stories of the book. (Langston Hughes's also is good) -

Well, don't let the Watergate affair spoil your Midwestern humor, and be well and as happy as one can be in this "brave new world" of ours -

My best to both of you    S. Lehmann

in pencil Lehmann-Chenneviere, Suzanne [no date]
4 Square de Verdun, Paris 10[?]
December 27
Dear Jack Conroy -

It's an awfully long time since I heard from you last and I am wondering what you and your family

are doing. I hope you are all well and prosperous. Have you had anything published since the display of
your books at the public library? I don't think I got news from you ever since -

Personally I've been through a lot

of troubles in my work. The "bulletin" I was publishing has been stopped - openly for ecansnay? sake, in fact,
for other reasons which you can guess - and though I've remained at the Agency, I don't do anything
interesting any longer - So my work time being devoid of interest, I try interesting holidays. I spent
a fortnight in Yugoslavia last Summer, and was thrilled with the social relations I saw. I am very much
afraid they won't

last though - Ever since my return, I read in the papers that many changes have happened - all for the worse.
then last month I was sent to Strasbourg for the conference between American confressners? and members of the
European Assembly - the only interesting thing I've done for 2 years at the Agency - It was rather amusing
to see how bewildered your representatives were when the Europeans wouldn't be persuaded to unify. It was
so very evident that here, nobody, not even those who say they do - is as afraid of a war as your people are -
When the American delegates said the danger is imminent, the Europeans said yes - But if they were sincere, would
they be so particular about the means to save themselves? (But of course I never wrote anything of this to my Agency)

 Well dear Jack this letter will take my best greetings to you and your people. Let me hear from you when you have a moment.
    Bien cardialement a vous            S. Chenneviere

[Best regards to you]

postcard  photo of church, sidewalk cafe
29 - Paris St Germain des Tres

I understand that you are feeling the financial effects of the present economic situation.
Different friends in the U.s. give me the same sort of news. this sounds like the depression of the thirties.
It is different in France. Up to now, the French have not had to cut their expenses.there are 1.200.000 out of work,
slacking production, incredible inflation. Nevertheless the shops of luxury food, the department stores, the jewelleries [sic],
had never sold so much for Christmas as they did this year. And the travel agencies couldn't satisfy all those who wanted to go 
to winder sports. Don't believe that the customers and tourists are all capitalists, far from it, they are just ordinary people.
I do not understand, but I am sure it can't last for long.
printed
ART PICTURAL PARIS
Made in France

Sarah Greenbaum
1819 Lincoln Park West
Chicago 14
June the 11th
Dear Mrs Conroy

dear Jack -
 This is to say good bye, and to thank you again for the very nice

evening I spent at your house. I am so very glad I have come to know
you two after all these years, and hope we'll meet again some time -
In the meanwhile, I'll very much appreciate a continuation through mail
of our "collaboration" in newspaperwork and poetry -

Remember me please to your daughter and sons.
Hoping to hear from you soon, I remain,
 yours cordially
   S. Chenneviere

From the 13th to the 26th:
c/o Sarah Greenbaum
Menemsha
Martha's Vineyard (Mass.)
Expect to be home in Paris on the 4th of July.

HENRI LEHMANN
Sous-Directeur Du Musee De L'Homme

6th floor - door to the left  17.30    Paris 16

[[crossed out - Musee De L'Homme
Palais De Chaillot]]

2 rue Livingston (18 e)
dans la rue Orsel
entrer par le rue de Clignancourt
on the street Orsel, enter by the street Clignancourt
3 dimensional wood carving - man with book

Dear Jack - I've been glad to see your "Disinherited" reprinted - It may get a large audience by now,
when there is a whole generation that doesn't know anything about the  30's. I still think your book is a
document and must be read by any student of those times.  I liked Aaron's introduction - I suppose it's
rather skillful -   Hope everything is all right for you and Gladys - We are getting some rest right now in
our Normandy house, in view of a more important trip to Egypt, due next month - we are reading books of
all sorts about Egypt but I still feel very ignorant. Five thousand years of history is rather heavy to digest, though fascinating.

Love to you both from the two of us
 S. Lehmann

printed on side
CAEN. Abbaye aux Hommes. Eglise St. Etienne.
74. Misericorde de stalle (XVII s.): le lecteur.
at bottom Editions Gaud, 16 rue Edeline, Rueil-Malmaison.

card woodcut picture of 3 religious men or scribes

Dear friends. How have you been this year and what have you been doing? As far as I am concerned,
I haven't much to say. I've just been living on. I am still with my Press Agency staff, and I guess I'll 
remain with it till the end of my career. It is not an exhilarating, but a moderately interesting job. Of
course we've had thrilling news this year - the Sputnik story for one -

but somehow, I've learnt to doubt progress. I'd rather have more order
at home than grand expeditions in the Cosmos.

Anyway I hope that our world will be safe for another year, and that it will

be a good year for you two -   Best regards

   S. Chenneviere

printed in red  MEILLEURS VOEUX [Best wishes]

AIR CANADA

in pencil Chomyk, Mike 1988
2/28/88 - Dear Jack: I got a note from Wixson about your being in a hospital - I was
out of town when the letter came and this is my first opportunity to give you my best
wishes for your recovery.

 Enclosed, are copies of some book inscriptions by you - Wally and Jack Balch to remind you of the 

"old days"  - what Hell-raisers we were -      Best    Mike Chomyk
in different handwriting

 For My old friend
 Mike Chomyk
  who can almost out-jump
Som patch, as he proved on one
cold winter's night in December
1947, when, at Frittertitter Towers,
he performed with Marvelous
agility, the Slobbonian sword
 dance
 J "Leaping" Conroy

Chicago May 20, 1951
Conroy's Folly

Dear Mike:

Wished you knew a friend of mine name of

Michael O'Hamster - a fine painter from
the old Ukranian soil  there is a man!

Here's looking at you anyway and the

same for Ethel.    Jack Bulib

To Mike Chomyk, the rare combination of a gifted genius
in the arts, and a man with a kind heart and a lively intelligence,
my friend, I dedicate my share of this book

 Will Wharton   Wallie

and likewise to his talented wife, wize [sic], witty and lovely.

 W W

__________________________

Hello. Mike - Laugh at this book and say it's funny - 

even if you don't think it is --

Wharton and I need the dough
 Jack "Adonais" Conroy

RUTGERS  THE STATE UNIVERSITY
Department of English
Newark, New Jersey 07102
September 3, 70
Dear Jack Conroy:

 Sorry about the delay of this material. I've had my troubles this summer - which is no excuse,

but maybe you'll understand. A letter from me should follow soon. Meanwhile - thank's for your
information and aid. I really appreciate it - and if you're burned, I don't blame you. But it couldn't be helped.

 yours truly -
  Henry A. Christian

435 Wyoming Ave.
Millburn, N.J. 07041

Dear Jack Conroy -

 I'm slogging along - not liking anything very much lately and not

getting a hell of a lot done as a result - but I thought maybe things would begin
to change if I spent a little time writing a good Christmas and a great coming

year to a good guy that I should write to more often -
so I'm doing it -

 best ever    Henry Christian

printed   Merry Christmas

Jack -

This year didn't go well - and I'll skip the details.
 For the marking of the 30th year after Adamic's? death, there will be

a symposium at the Immigration History Research Center at the Univ.
of Minnisota [sic] in May - and another in Ljubljania, Yugoslavia, in September.
I'm supposed to perform at both.   I'm using The Disinherited in

in pencil  Christian, Henry
1980
To Jack Conroy and his wife Gladys

 Best wishes for a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year
  Henry Christian

my advanced course in 20th C. Am. lit. again this Spring. I'll let you know
if any really new ideas about it come from my students. The message of this
quilt is mine to you in Moberly.      H.

This Six Point star was made as a friendship quilt for Sarah Ann VanWagoner

in 1849. Each white block was inscribed by friends who were welcoming her
when she visited her grandmother and aunt in Newark at Christmas. One of the
verses, visible on this section reads.

"The skies that cover thee I pray
   May never wear a frown
 And love that strengthens day by day
  Thy early friendship crown."

Purchased from a direct descendant of the original owner, 1976.
Collection of the Newark Museum, Newark, N.J.
______
Patchwork Graphics, Inc. 1980
P.O. Box 304 Old Chelsea Station
New York, N.Y. 10011

in pencil Christian, Henry  1988
printed in red  Best wished for a happy holiday

All my cards are late this year, but well meant.

Never reached me you were feeling poorly - but I
know you will come up again. The old tough ones like
you always do.

If I missed a card to you last year, it

was because my boy died in 1987. His poor old bad heart and lungs from birth
just couldn't go beyond 25 yrs. But it's OK; the MD's said he wouldn't make 25 arelos?!

 I was in Berlin in March - both sides - and you can still tell the East from the West, believe me. 

Then in May I gave another paper in Yugoslavia. But? I'll be home now for a while. I think
of you - taught The Disinherited again this semester. Ulz? exam question

was which charcter [sic] was most free and which least free in all the readings. About
1/3 of the class chose Larry as least free. This may be a hard winter, but better is
ahead - you taught me that!

 Henry Christian

typed Arthur Church    Nov. 21, 1952
Dear Brother Conroy & assorted sisters -

Received your kind messages & am passing out the Word of God to the nurses who seem to

take the messages to heart - possibly because I'm the only eligible bachelor on the floor - figuratively
speaking of course since I haven't left my bed of nonetoogreat pain since I arrived - prospect is
for more of same, a year of special diet - no liquor - and, as the doctor delicately phrases it, no
similar indiscretions for an extended period - I take this to include the 7 sins that cry out to heaven for vengence [sic],
the 7 deadly sins, not to mention bestiality, thumb-sucking, and goosing nuns.

Tests are not yet in completely and I have no idea how long I shall be absent from the salt mines. I will have mother

tell Mr Fiske all as soon as we know. If I don't get back very soon, there are notes which may make some slight sense -
I doubt it - in the file and a couple of drafts for articles in the Center

drawer of the desk. I bought a picture from Mrs Code to accompany the Siena sculpture
thing, and your friend Peter Pollack said he could provide photos of several paintings in
the Fauve show - these & a couple of scraps are all I can provide - altho there is a list
(I believe accurate) of the new Senators elect & Newsweek supplement has a list of the
governors.

 I don't know if the Southern belle is working on the consolidated index - might check.
 I hope this sounds more efficient than I feel. My hobby is writing down Inake & Output.

When they balance I guess I get a prize

  Love & Kisses to you all   A C

Pardon pencil - the only item I possess that has lead in it -

in pencil Church, Arthur [no date]
Dear Jack -

 Nothing new but I'm hot on the trail of 3 jobs - 2 seem close to definite.

Here is a rough draft of a resume I've started using - any inquiries you or Bob may get will be 
based on it. Don't fail me - I've got enough tan & water in my ears. Now I want to start working.
One job is with the American Locomotive Co. Maybe I'll name a diesel after you.

Enclosed find ad for a play you must see.
  Arthur

in pencil  Church, Arthur [no date]
Dear Jack -

Just a brief note. I feel you should be informed of this case of poetic justice

As well as a piece of timely advice.

I apparently have a job, but do not start for several days so will let you know

more (as well as my new address) when job & Apt. appear on the scene.

 Arthur

Jane Clark

Bellwood, Ills

if you want to see them. Just let me know.

Merry Christmas  I just reread your good letter written a year ago -
Shameful I never replied. A different year. I am in "Dylan."
We play New Haven, Toronto, then N.Y. in Jan.

Ben G.

Tuesday the 8th
Dear Jack -

I know I'm safe in addressing you as "Honorable" as if Jack Conroy has been in Moberly,

Missouri for a week - believe me he is! Am writing this before the election results are published
or for that matter - settled. It's raining like hell and I  hope the good Lord (get out your tract,
Jack if you don't know what the word means) keeps it coming, as I'm sure the Christian Scientists
[[in green] A Sound Investment in Your Child's Future

Don't like their member enough to get wet.

Say that was a good article that Bradley wrote on your exodus. I was sorry that I didn't feel well the night of the 

Standard party. If they'd asked me I would have told them to give you the money & we could have gone dutch
treat to one of the more respectable bars that Rothschild owns on West Madison St. Seriously, I was sorry that I
couldn't be there. But I know that even if you are living on Fisk Ave - you'll soon be

riding the rails back to our beautiful, and as of this moment, Democratic city!

Be sure to let me know the date!

My very best wishes for your wife's and your "good health" and happiness!"
As ever,    Bob      Have fun!!

card drawing of children from different cultures, eating

Many Children Dwell in My Fathers House     Amen

Xmas '65
Dear Jack,

I phoned Barbara at her bookstore & it seemed to me that she was a bit busy at the time but in any case, I need twelve of your books, she

had only nine, and said she could not order any extras for me. Not to worry. I'll order the lot from Chandler's where Jerry gets a faculty discount & which
Barbara says she cannot give - fair enough, though perhaps for that many books I should order where our faculty discount is no problem.

Another story of mine will appear in EPOCH soon and I'd like to send you a reprint.
Did you see in the Midland Authors bulletin where Saul Bellow is compiling - has compiled? - an anthology of Chicago writers stories & novels?

Will you be in it? I would expect so.

I hope to see you soon. Perhaps you & your wife can pay us a visit after the holidays & mud season?
   Best wishes    Florence Cohen

Florence Cohen
125 Laurel Avenue - h/w New Address
Wilmette, Illinois 60091 in pencil: no date
April 6
Dear Jack,

It's good to have a reason to write to you again. Ford, I hope your winter went better than ours because here it was a mess and still is,

no spring yet and maybe never. Actually, I don't feel that pessimistic. I think I told you in my Christmas letter about being Writer-in-Residence
at Barat College in Lake Forest. It's been a good experience messing around a college and feeling sort of phony academic but very respectable.
The good sisters at Barat seemed to have thrown off their nun's clothes like bad habits and now wear pants, mini's, red hose, white leather boots
and even, God help us, one had on false eyelashes I swear, which sent a great chill through me - the ecumenical identity crisis can only get worse
from there and I can only imagine that the sisters will soon be teaching courses on Lenny Bruce.

Anyway, as Barat is next door to Lake Forest College (a very good place) I've met some clever English people who seem to know what they're doing.

I want to tell you about one professor in particular, a young man by name of Robert Greenfield, whose field is contemporary Amer. lit. and ^who has
told me that he's been toying with the idea of doing a book on Jack Conroy, author of The Disinherited.

"Toy no more", I shouted - "Start writing!"      We had a very long talk about you - I told him he'd never regret doing a book on

you, etc. etc., and as it stands now he is planning to do at least a long paper or monograph type thing,
but something. I gave him your address & he'll write you and, of course, I'm delighted. I think this will
good all round - he wants to see & talk to you, he said, and it would be so great if you could get to Chi sometime.

As for me, the teaching duties sponge up writing time and that depresses me but I hope to remedy this - I suppose

there's never enough time for things and the trick is to gauge it out somehow.

My book never got a Chicago review but the Journal of Eng, Amer Library Rev, & Kirkus Review did very well

by me -    Do write & tell me how things are going. Are you pleased about this biog being planned now by Bob
Greenfield? If there's anything you want to know about the kind of fellow he is I'll be glad to tell you all I know.

With best wishes to Gladys.      Florence Cohen.

P.S. Jerome sends love & hope we can have a get-together soon.

than our thanks, applause and laughter. That's all we have for you this year, but we do have

I hope you had as good a time as the audience.     Jack Condon

April 3

Dear Jack -

Well, me lucky your review was welcome and needed, the best of the lot.

Everybody has sent me copies of it. I've a dozen or fifteen!

Have just had a hernia operation at this place. Leaving tomorrow. Will be home

before you get this.   Glad you got in touch with ?ngoff. Let's keep contact

Old timer    Earl

in pencil Conrad, Earl [no date]
"Buffalo" Bob Smith's                    Phone  LOgan 6-5436
Villa Venice Apartments
2900 Terramar St.
Fort Lauderdale, Florida
My dear Jack -

Nice to get your note and very kind of you, as usual, to take care of the new one. I've written to

B.Geis? Co. to make sure you get a copy

Enjoyed the reviews you sent and I agree on the Arons book, on the basis of your review. I haven't

seen the book.

Am nursing myself along here.  By the way, if there is ever anything I can do for you publicationwise in

N.Y. do not hesitate to ask.    Let's keep in touch.

 Yours,  Earl.

Dear Jack:

Sorry I couldn't attend your autographing party in Chicago but we were out of town at a

wedding that Saturday.

If you have any hard cover copies of your new book on hand could you send me one?

Enclosed is check which I hope will cover the cost of the book plus mailing.

Hope you will do well with it and that it wont be too long before your biography is

published.

From time to time I have a free-lance piece published in the Tribune, etc. and have a

novel that I have hopes for. Also plan to go into business after the holidays with a gimmick
I devised along with an artistic partner. Will send you a copy

of the item when they're ready to go.  Hope all is well in Moberly and that your winter down there
is one of the mild ones in recent years.  

(Today Sunday - Dec 16 - my bird bath has a foot of white flakes all stuck together on top - a good

day not to be in Chicago land)

Will be looking forward to receiving the book - autographed, I hope - but please do not rush it. Next time

you're down at the post office will be great but don't make a special trip on my account  Or if you haven't
any copies handy just have it sent out from where-ever your published mails one - and  will forge your
auto graph.

Best always -   Bette Conroy

Dear Jack  We keep up with your activities via the many mentions you get in the Chicago book reviews.  My daughter who is 16 took your review of the new Mark Twain biography to her English class last week - very proud of her namesake!  Right away we are going to send to the U. of Missouri at Kansas City to see if we can get a copy of New Letters.  Didn’t know until now that your new book is so far along and are looking forward to publication day.  No doubt you already saw the enclosed review from a recent Tribune Book World - but in case you missed it - thought you’d get a kick out of reading about a

prior Conroy whose eye was on the main chance, apparently.  Enclosed are a couple of things I had published this year that you might want to read.  I have some other parodies coming up in the Journalism Review - but I think that little publication just ain’t what it was in its early days. It’s gotten quite, sour, shrill and pompous like a lot of publications that let the compliments delude to the point where they lose their flair and style.  Hope you are having a pleasant winter in Moberly.  If you saw the ice supply and the people wearing

plaster casts all over Chicagoland you would be delighted that you had the foresight to move a trifle southward.  Well- best of luck to you in all your endeavors and here’s to 1973 being a splendid year for all the Conroys and the other people unlucky enough to be wearing other last names.  Bette Conroy

Printed letterhead:  Young & Rubicam, Inc., Advertising, New York Chicago Detroit San Francisco Los Angeles Hollywood Montreal Toronto Mexico City London, New York 17, 285 Madison Avenue
February 10, 1958
Dear Jack - A belated but sincere thank-you for the “Garland of Midwest corn blossoms “ - enjoyed the collection very much.  I’m working here at Y & R as an art director and haven’t done any jackets or book or book illustrations in years but thought I’d send along the enclosed, beat-up copy of “Man Without a Country “ which I worked on 8 or 9 years ago.  The drawings are a bit on the naive side but the author, if no one else, had no adverse criticism to make.  If I ever get to Chicago, or you to New York, perhaps we could get together and lift a toast or two, to Ir.  Sincerely - Jack Conroy pencil notation: not Jack Conroy
